S6.T1.caption: Table 1. Performance (accuracy for MNIST & Cifar-10 – higher is better, perplexity for WikiText-2 – lower is better) of each algorithm after some number of seconds (750 for MNIST, 7000 for Cifar-10, 600 for WikiText-2). Each experiment is repeated three times. The values are the average time and the standard deviation. A * denotes that the algorithm did not run up to the selected time threshold. NA denotes the lack of any valid result. There are 40 clients including 10 faulty ones.

references: We evaluate Catalyst in two typical application scenarios: image classification (He et al., 2016; Oh et al., 2022; Li et al., 2021a) and word prediction (Lin et al., 2018; McMahan et al., 2017) as summarized in Table 1 and Table 2.

Table 1 shows the results we obtained for our three tasks and the examined baselines, along with Catalyst.
The left-hand side of the table shows the performance for the no-attack (f=0𝑓0f=0) case. Here, thanks to its insensitivity to learning rate, Kardam performs best over the image datasets, while on the other end of the spectrum, FedAsync often struggles already. When switching to text data, BASGD and Catalyst perform very similarly, besting the others. Overall, Catalyst provides consistently high performance across all tested datasets before and after introducing attackers.

The middle column of Table 1 tackles the random perturbation attack, where both FedAsync and Kardam show weaknesses, often not running long enough to reach the target wall time. BASGD performs well, and Catalyst does even better. Catalyst has 5 or more additional percentage points of accuracy over BASGD in both MNIST and Cifar-10, with the lead in WikiText-2 being even more substantial at over 600 points. Catalyst still achieves scores similar to its own when no attack exists. The tested instance of the attack has strength σ=0.1𝜎0.1\sigma{=}0.1.

To provide a more comprehensive comparison with the baselines over the different parts of a training cycle, we plot the accuracy/perplexity of resulting models concerning the wall time. The settings for (Byzantine) clients and the servers are the same as for Table 1. Due to its greater disruption capabilities, we focus on the no-attack case as a preliminary check and gradient inversion.

Figure 4 shows the two scenarios for MNIST. Without attack (Figure 4(a)), the trends from Table 1 are reconfirmed, with the one note that BASGD, unlike the others, appears to struggle to converge. During an attack (Figure 4(b)), Catalyst maintains its speed of convergence, and still tops out at over 95% accuracy, with BASGD improving considerably to claim the runner-up place. Kardam is unable to mitigate the attack for too long, and it also suffers from a large variance between runs, as its filtering mechanism proves unreliable. FedAsync manages to run longer than Kardam, but to no avail, as it never makes any progress in terms of model quality.
